incorporation_agency: New York Department of State - Division of Corporations
charitable_registration_agency: New York Attorney General - Charities Bureau
exemption_threshold_note: Organizations with gross receipts under $25,000 annually that receive contributions from fewer than 100 contributors may be exempt from charitable registration, but must file a simple registration statement.

formation_requirements.notes: New York does not require a registered agent but requires a 'service of process' address. Certificate must include statement that corporation is formed under the Not-For-Profit Corporation Law.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Department of State - Division of Corporations
requirements.due_date_specifics: Due every two years during the calendar month of incorporation
required_information: Names and addresses of principal officers
requirements.notes: Filing is required every two years, not annually. Late filings incur $25 penalty. Failure to file can result in administrative dissolution.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Attorney General - Charities Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Within 30 days of receiving $25,000 in contributions or soliciting from 100+ contributors
required_information: List of directors and officers with addresses
requirements.notes: Registration is free but mandatory for most charities. Small organizations may file simplified CHAR410-S. Registration must be renewed annually via CHAR500.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Attorney General - Charities Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Within 6 months after fiscal year end (4.5 months if using extension)
requirements.form_number: CHAR500 - Annual Filing for Charitable Organizations
required_information: Updated list of directors and officers
requirements.notes: This is the annual renewal of charitable registration. Late filing can result in fines up to $1,000. Organizations may file automatically via IRS 990 if under revenue thresholds.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Department of Taxation and Finance
requirements.due_date_specifics: File after receiving IRS 501(c) determination letter
required_information: Description of organization's purposes and activities
requirements.notes: Form ST-119.1 is for organizations exempt under IRC 501(c)(3). Form ST-119 is for other qualifying organizations. Once approved, exemption is permanent but organization must provide exemption certificate to vendors. Not all purchases are exempt - review specific exemptions.

requirements.requirement_name: Real Property Tax Exemption Application (Form RP-420)
requirements.filing_agency: Local Assessor's Office and State Board of Real Property Services
requirements.due_date_specifics: March 1st (Taxable Status Date) for exemption beginning the following tax year
requirements.form_number: Form RP-420-a (Initial Application) or RP-420-b (Claim for Exemption)
required_information: Deed or proof of property ownership
Description of property use for exempt purposes
requirements.notes: Property must be owned by the nonprofit and used exclusively for exempt purposes. Initial application (RP-420-a) includes $500 filing fee. Annual exemption claims (RP-420-b) have no fee. Exemption must be renewed annually in most jurisdictions.

requirements.filing_agency: Municipal Clerk or Racing and Wagering Board (for multi-municipal events)
requirements.due_date_specifics: File application at least 30 days before gaming event
requirements.form_number: GC-7 Series Forms (varies by game type)
required_information: Proof of incorporation in New York
Proof of 1+ years operation in community
List of officers and game managers
Proposed game dates, times, and locations
requirements.notes: New York permits bingo, raffles, bell jars, and other games of chance for qualified nonprofits. Organization must be incorporated in NY for at least 1 year. Maximum prizes and frequency limits apply. Professional management prohibited.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Attorney General - Charities Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Renewed annually from initial registration date
requirements.form_number: CHAR401 - Registration Statement for Fundraising Counsel
required_information: List of persons with management responsibility
List of current charity clients in New York
requirements.notes: Fundraising counsel provides consulting services but does not solicit or receive contributions. Paid employees of registered charities are exempt.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Attorney General - Charities Bureau
requirements.due_date_specifics: Renewed annually from initial registration date
requirements.form_number: CHAR500-PF - Registration Statement for Professional Fundraiser
required_information: List of persons with management responsibility
List of current charity clients and campaigns
requirements.notes: Professional fundraisers solicit contributions on behalf of charities. Each contract must be filed with Charities Bureau on Schedule 4-A within 10 days. Bond must be maintained throughout registration.

requirements.filing_agency: Internal requirement - filed with board and included in CHAR500 filing
requirements.due_date_specifics: Within 180 days after fiscal year end (completed before CHAR500 due date)
required_information: Audited financial statements (Statement of Financial Position, Activities, Cash Flows)
requirements.notes: Required for organizations with gross revenues over $1,000,000 in the current or either of two preceding fiscal years. Organizations between $500,000-$1,000,000 must have an independent review. Organizations under $500,000 may prepare internally compiled statements. Audit must be performed by independent CPA licensed in New York.

requirements.filing_agency: New York Attorney General - Charities Bureau (included in CHAR500)
required_information: Annual disclosure statements from directors and officers
Documentation of conflict review and resolution process
requirements.notes: New York requires written conflicts of interest policies and annual disclosure statements from board members. Charities must certify on CHAR500 that they have adopted and implemented such policies.

special_notes.strict_registration: New York has some of the most comprehensive charitable registration requirements in the U.S. The Charities Bureau actively monitors compliance and can impose significant penalties for non-compliance.
special_notes.char500_filing: The CHAR500 annual filing is mandatory for all registered charities, regardless of size. Organizations with revenues under $250,000 may use simplified CHAR500-Short form.
special_notes.professional_fundraiser_contracts: Every contract with a professional fundraiser or fundraising counsel must be filed with the Attorney General within 10 days of execution using Schedule 4-A. Failure to file can result in fines.
special_notes.board_requirements: New York nonprofit corporations must have at least three directors. Directors serve staggered terms as specified in bylaws. Board must meet regularly and maintain minutes.
special_notes.conflict_of_interest_mandatory: Unlike many states, New York legally requires all nonprofits to adopt and implement a written conflicts of interest policy. Annual compliance must be certified on CHAR500.
special_notes.political_activity_limits: 501(c)(3) organizations must comply with federal restrictions on political campaign intervention and lobbying. New York law mirrors and reinforces these federal limits.
special_notes.property_tax_complexity: Property tax exemption in New York is complex with many local variations. Initial application fee of $500 applies. Exemption typically requires annual renewal claims.
special_notes.gaming_restrictions: New York gaming laws are complex. Organizations must be incorporated in New York for at least 1 year before conducting games of chance. Professional operation is prohibited.
special_notes.financial_thresholds: Key thresholds: $25,000 triggers charitable registration, $250,000 enables CHAR500-Short form, $500,000 requires financial review, $1,000,000 requires independent audit.
special_notes.ubit_filing: Organizations with unrelated business income over $1,000 must file IRS Form 990-T and New York Corporation Tax Return (CT-13) if conducting business in New York.
special_notes.dissolution_assets: Upon dissolution, assets must be distributed to organizations with similar charitable purposes or to government. Attorney General must approve dissolution plans for registered charities.
special_notes.registration_reciprocity: New York does not participate in the Unified Registration Statement (URS) for multi-state charitable solicitation. Separate NY-specific forms are required.
